Award.AwardTitle: Ichishkiin/Sahaptin (yak): Language Documentation of Natural and Cultural Resources

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a collaboration between programs of the Yakama Nation and the Northwest Indian Language Institute at the University of Oregon. Each elder of the Yakama Nation holds unique and irreplaceable knowledge of the language, and about specific places and the natural and cultural resources found there. Elders will be recorded speaking to the broad themes of places and cultural and natural resource management and preservation. To Yakama tribal members, land is not just ground, dirt or soil, it is tiichám. Water is not H2O, or merely something to be adjudicated, it is chiish. Salmon is not just a fish, chinook or Oncorhynchus tshawytscha, it is núsux. The greater importance of these resources, and all that their Yakama names represent, is expanded upon and reinforced in the Yakama language by elders through recollections, stories, songs and ceremonies.

The Ichishkíin language, also called Sahaptin (Sahaptian, Plateau Penutian) is highly endangered, thus this documentation work will not be possible much longer. Products and results of the project include (i) a collection of audio and video recordings of narratives, procedural texts, interviews and conversations related to themes of resources and places that are transcribed, translated and archived; and an annotated subset; (ii) a database of the above recordings and associated analysis; (iii) a catalog of the natural resources of the Yakama Nation -- culturally significant plants, animals, fish, birds, and insects, with text in Ichiskíin and English, and associated recordings and photos; (iv) an archive of all recordings and products; (v) training of speech community members in audio and video recording, text transcription, and data management. The data collected will enrich not only the field of linguistics, but also that of natural and cultural resource identification, use and protection. Training will enhance the community's ability to continue documenting their language and cultural activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ichishkiin/Sahaptin (yak): Language Documentation

of Natural and Cultural Resources

 

To speakers of the Yakama Ichishkíin (Sahaptin) language, land is not just ground, dirt or soil, it is tiichám. Water is not H2O, or merely something to be managed, it is chuush. Salmon is not just a fish, chinook or Oncorhynchus tshawytscha, it is núsux. In a special ka’úyt (first foods) ceremony, salmon is wayk’áanash. The greater importance of these resources, and all that their names represent, is expanded upon and reinforced in the Yakama language by elders’ unique and irreplaceable recollections and stories about places and the natural and cultural resources found there. The elders learned about resources in the Ichishkíin language; the Ichishkíin language holds information and recollections in a way that the English language never can.

The project promotes the continued stabilization of the Ichishkíin language, life ways and culture through language documentation, specifically in recording Ichishkíin-speaking elders discussing the broad themes of places and cultural and natural resource management and conservation within the homelands of the Yakama people. It encompasses language documentation and linguistic analysis as well as training of tribal members in high-quality audio and video recording, text transcription, and data management. The project documents the knowledge of the elders in their own language; supports and strengthens natural and cultural resource management; provides teachers of language and culture with a better description of the language and rich materials and resources for lessons; adds to efforts to teach and preserve Ichishkíin; and builds capacity for future projects through training.

Due to the specific topic focus of the project, the data collected enhance not only the field of linguistics, but also those of natural and cultural resource identification, use and protection. Via the project, resource managers can listen to the elders’ words and use them to make better management decisions through an improved understanding of the resources, language and culture. The project allows us to better describe and understand the Ichishkíin language (Sahaptian, Plateau Penutian), which shows many features of great potential interest to theoretical, typological, and areal linguistics. The Penutian hypothesis has important implications for our understanding of the languages of Western North America. Furthermore, studies of Penutian and the place of Ichishkíin within it, and of the genetic inheritance and areal influences which have shaped Penutian, also are of value to students of the archaeology and history of western North America. This understanding is important in the modern legal context in which scientific testimony concerning the history of settlement and migration patterns can play an important role in land use and other legal issues.    

Within the project, Elders were recorded talking about areas on the reservation and the ways those areas have changed in their lifetimes; foods; hunting practices; particular plant resources. For example, one Elder spoke of growing up in the mountains, near the timberline, with aunts and grandmothers. Their remote and subsistence living depended on gathering, fishing, and hunting small game. Another elder spoke at a wetlands, identifying some of the plants found there and speaking of their uses and importance. A female elder talked of root gathering and root foods. The project also included previously-collected texts and recordings. Sound files and texts pass on the knowledge of some of the last Elder speakers, and ensure future generations the raw materials and tools to continue research. Importantly, the collected materials cover a number of the mutually intelligible dialects spoken, fulfilling the goal that the range of dialects spoken by Yakama Nation members be represented, not only the Yakama dialect.

The project provided linguistics and documentation training to Yakama Nation members and university students. Yakama Nation Language Program staff, tribal youth, and students were trained in audio and video recording, documentation practices, and data management. The project's training enhanced the community’s ability to continue documenting their language and other events and cultural activities.
